title: Expand Strudel toolkit with energy templates and density rules
description:
# Expand Strudel Toolkit with Energy Templates and Density Rules

## Context
Each agent prompt in .claude/agents/*.md has a <strudel_toolkit> section with ~10 lines of Strudel code examples. Strudel is a niche DSL (TidalCycles-inspired browser synth). Claude Haiku generates Strudel code using only this thin reference. This leads to frequent syntax errors, invalid function usage, and patterns that fail to evaluate in the browser.

## Why This Change
Agents need a richer vocabulary to generate valid, diverse patterns. The toolkit should cover more functions, show anti-patterns (what NOT to do), provide energy-keyed templates, and set density constraints tied to energy level.

## What to Change (per agent)

### 1. Expand <strudel_toolkit> (~30-40 lines)
Add more Strudel functions relevant to each agent's role:
- Drums: .struct(), .euclid() variations, .mask(), multiple bank options
- Bass: .legato(), .sustain(), octave patterns, .slide()
- Melody: .arp(), .palindrome(), .rev(), .superimpose(), .off()
- FX: .phaser(), .chorus(), .leslie(), .waveloss(), .shape()

### 2. Add <common_errors> section
Per-agent anti-patterns:
- ALL: "Do NOT wrap patterns in markdown code fences (```). Output raw Strudel code in the JSON string."
- Drums: "NEVER use note() for drums. Use s() only. Invalid: note('c4').s('bd'). Valid: s('bd').bank('RolandTR909')"
- Bass: "NEVER go above c3. NEVER use s() without note(). Invalid: s('sawtooth'). Valid: note('c1').s('sawtooth')"
- Melody: "NEVER go below c4 (that's GROOVE's range). NEVER use s() for drum sounds."
- FX: "ALWAYS include .hpf(300) or higher. Without it, you'll muddy GROOVE's bass range."

### 3. Add energy-band pattern skeletons
One template per energy level (low/mid/high) that agents can use as starting points:
- Drums low (1-3): s("bd ~ ~ ~").bank("RolandTR909")
- Drums mid (4-6): stack(s("bd ~ sd ~").bank("RolandTR909"), s("hh*4").gain(0.5))
- Drums high (7-10): stack(s("bd [~ bd] sd [bd ~]").bank("RolandTR909"), s("hh*8").gain(0.5), s("~ ~ ~ cp"))
(Similar for bass, melody, fx — tailored to each instrument)

### 4. Add density-to-energy rule
Add to <musical_rules> or <strudel_toolkit>:
"Pattern density should match energy: Energy 1-3: use at most 1 layer (no stack). Energy 4-6: up to 2 layers in your own stack(). Energy 7-10: up to 3 layers in your own stack()."

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

## Acceptance Criteria
- Each agent's <strudel_toolkit> has 30+ lines of reference
- Each agent has a <common_errors> section with 3-5 anti-patterns
- Each agent has 3 energy-band pattern skeletons (low/mid/high)
- Density rule appears in each file
- All example patterns in the toolkit are valid Strudel code

title: Race condition between auto-tick and boss directives in AgentProcessManager
description:
## Summary
`AgentProcessManager` can process auto-tick and boss-directive turns concurrently on the same agent process pipes, creating a race condition in stdin/stdout turn handling.

## Evidence
- Auto-tick runs every 30s:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:456`
- Guard exists only for tick-vs-tick overlap (`tickInProgress`), not directive-vs-tick overlap:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:457`
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:129`
- Each send path installs a readline listener and waits for `result`:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:337`

## Why This Matters
Concurrent turns can interleave stream-json events and misattribute responses, causing stale/mixed state updates and unpredictable musical behavior.

## Proposed Direction
Introduce per-manager (or per-agent) turn serialization: a command queue/mutex ensuring only one active request per agent process at a time. Auto-tick should skip/defer when directives are in flight.
acceptance_criteria:
1. Boss directives and auto-ticks cannot execute concurrently against the same agent process.
2. Message-response matching is deterministic under load (no cross-assigned responses).
3. Add a stress/regression test that simulates directive arrival near tick boundary.
4. Logging clearly indicates skipped/deferred ticks while directives are in progress.

2026-02-25: Fixed intermittent jam-agent error transitions seen after directives where some columns showed error then appeared to recover on the 30s boundary. Root causes: (1) codex exec resume inherited global reasoning defaults (e.g., reasoning.effort=xhigh) incompatible with gpt-5-codex-mini; (2) auto-tick applied fallback status updates to unavailable agents, masking process failure. Resolution: runtime now injects profile-scoped + top-level reasoning overrides, jam manager uses jam profile defaults, normal mode uses normal profile defaults, auto-tick only targets live agents, and jam logs now surface parsed turn.failed payloads. Added regression test coverage for crashed-agent status persistence across auto-tick.

title: Model-driven Musical Policy via Skills (Jam + Runtime)
description:
Problem
Jam and runtime behavior currently mix high-freedom musical interpretation with deterministic hardcoded heuristics. This caused brittle outcomes (invalid Strudel methods, over-aggressive tempo shifts) and reactive patches.

Vision
The long-term vision is autonomous, organic music creation: agents should listen, respond, and evolve patterns with meaningful creative freedom, leveraging latent model intelligence instead of rigid phrase-by-phrase hardcoding.

Creative freedom principle
- Agents should be free to choose musical ideas, motifs, development arcs, and stylistic variation.
- Prompts should avoid over-prescriptive “play exactly this” instructions except where required for role boundaries or explicit boss directives.
- Strudel documentation should be the primary capability reference; examples should guide, not constrain.

Goal
Move musical interpretation decisions (tempo nuance, texture/motion choices, semantic intent) into model-driven policy using skills/prompts, while retaining only minimal deterministic safety rails.

Scope
- Jam mode policy (per-agent Codex-backed sessions)
- Normal mode policy where relevant for consistency
- Refactor/remove unnecessary hardcoded behavior introduced during debugging
- Audit existing hardcoded behavior and identify migrations to skills
- Audit and deconstrain prompts that unnecessarily restrict agent creativity

Architecture constraints to preserve
- Deterministic @mention routing in code
- Per-agent persistent jam sessions
- Server-side stack() composition
- WebSocket broadcast-callback pattern
- Jam agents remain toolless unless intentionally changed
- Agent role boundaries (instrument ownership / band role) remain explicit
acceptance_criteria:
1. Model-driven policy path exists for relative tempo/energy/arrangement decisions in jam mode with clear ownership boundaries.
2. Skills (or prompt modules) are created and integrated for musical decision policy and Strudel-valid output policy.
3. Session-introduced hardcoded rewrites/heuristics are either removed or reduced to minimal documented safety rails.
4. Hardcoded-policy audit is completed with explicit "keep in code" vs "migrate to skill" decisions and follow-up beads.
5. Prompt/persona audit confirms prompts preserve creative autonomy and avoid unnecessary over-constraint.
6. Tests/docs pass and no regressions in normal mode + jam mode.

title: Design policy boundary: model-owned musical decisions vs code-owned guarantees
description:
Define and document a boundary matrix for what remains deterministic in code versus what moves to model policy.

The boundary must explicitly support creative autonomy:
- Model-owned: interpretation of nuanced language, arrangement evolution, groove/timbre choices, expressive density shifts.
- Code-owned: routing, session/process lifecycle, hard safety bounds, schema validation, and deterministic precedence for explicit directives.

Include explicit precedence rules: explicit BPM directives > half/double time > model-relative tempo intent. Include failure behavior, fallback behavior, confidence handling, and autonomy-preserving defaults.
acceptance_criteria:
1. Boundary matrix doc committed (model-owned vs code-owned).
2. Precedence rules cover explicit tempo, relative tempo, energy, texture, and arrangement intent.
3. Failure-mode policy defined (invalid output, low confidence, no decision) without collapsing to overly rigid defaults.
4. Creative autonomy principle is explicitly documented with examples of allowed model latitude.
5. Architecture invariants from AGENTS.md are explicitly preserved.
close_reason: Canonical policy boundary doc is now docs/v3/model-policy-boundary.md (v3 source of truth).

title: Validation gate: regressions, latency, and behavioral acceptance
description: Run targeted/unit/integration checks to verify policy migration does not regress reliability or jam responsiveness. Validate representative directives (slight tempo, strong tempo, arrangement changes, FX changes) behave as expected.
acceptance_criteria:
1. Lint/tests/build pass for touched areas.
2. Behavioral acceptance checks documented with before/after examples.
3. No increase in critical runtime error rate for invalid pattern execution.
4. Epic completion checklist updated with evidence links.

title: Prompt De-Constraint Audit: preserve autonomous agent creativity
description:
Audit existing prompts and agent personas for over-constraint.

Files in scope (minimum):
- .codex/agents/*.md
- lib/codex-process.ts (normal mode SYSTEM_PROMPT)
- any shared prompt/reference blocks injected into jam agents

Review for patterns that may suppress creativity, including:
- overly specific mandatory examples
- rigid stylistic prescriptions presented as hard requirements
- instruction language that collapses expressive latitude without strong reason

Refactor prompts toward:
- role boundaries only (instrument/agent identity)
- Strudel validity and safety constraints
- broad creative autonomy in pattern generation and evolution
- guidance that examples are optional patterns, not required templates
acceptance_criteria:
1. Prompt inventory completed with per-file findings and over-constraint risk level.
2. Overly prescriptive instructions/examples are revised to optional guidance where appropriate.
3. Updated prompts explicitly preserve agent creative freedom while keeping role boundaries.
4. Strudel documentation remains primary capability reference; no regression in output validity goals.
5. Before/after evidence shows increased stylistic diversity for representative directives.
notes:
Completed prompt de-constraint pass across .codex/agents/*.md and lib/codex-process.ts SYSTEM_PROMPT.

Changes made:
- Removed over-prescriptive evolution scaffolding and rigid staged rules.
- Added explicit autonomy policy (model-owned musical decisions) while preserving safety/output rails.
- Made Strudel docs/resource the primary capability reference.
- Marked prompt examples as optional guidance, not required templates.
- Preserved role boundaries and boss-directive compliance guarantees.

Validation:
- npm run lint (pass)
- npx tsc --noEmit (pass)
Follow-up completion: extracted normal-mode SYSTEM_PROMPT from lib/codex-process.ts into .codex/agents/normal-mode-system-prompt.md and updated CodexProcess to load prompt from disk at runtime.

Implementation details:
- Added .codex/agents/normal-mode-system-prompt.md as the canonical normal-mode prompt body.
- Added file-loading path resolution in lib/codex-process.ts for .codex/agents/normal-mode-system-prompt.md (workingDir first, cwd fallback).
- Removed inlined prompt constant from TypeScript; build_prompt now uses loaded prompt text.

Validation:
- npm run lint (pass)
- npx tsc --noEmit (pass)
- npx vitest run lib/__tests__/codex-process-startup.test.ts lib/__tests__/codex-process-runtime-event-mapping.test.ts (pass)

title: Create jam-musical-policy skill for nuanced directive interpretation
description:

The skill should bias toward autonomous creativity while preserving musical coherence:

- Tempo/energy deltas by phrase strength.

Use Strudel docs as capability substrate, with minimal role boundaries (instrument ownership) and broad expressive freedom otherwise.

title: Add autonomous tick system for organic jam evolution
Sandbox environment blocks Workstream G benchmark execution
description:
## Summary
Workstream G benchmark execution is blocked in the current sandbox environment by local networking and Codex connectivity failures.

## Reproduction
1. Run `npm run dev`.
2. Run `npm run benchmark:workstream-g -- --jam-start-runs 2 --targeted-runs 2 --broadcast-runs 2 --timeout-ms 20000`.
3. Run a direct Codex inference command from repo root.

## Observed Failures
1. `next dev` fails to bind: `listen EPERM` on `:3000`.
2. Benchmark websocket connect fails: `connect EPERM` to `127.0.0.1:3000` and `::1:3000`.
3. Direct Codex inference fails with repeated stream disconnects to `https://chatgpt.com/backend-api/codex/responses`.

## Impact
- Blocks Workstream G acceptance criterion requiring benchmark report with dated p95 latency.
- Prevents validating staged rollout gate under this sandbox.

## Notes
- Regression gates (`lint`, `vitest`, `build`) pass locally in this environment.
- Benchmark harness is already implemented at `scripts/benchmarks/run-bsj-6ud-1-benchmark.mjs`.
acceptance_criteria:
1. next dev can bind to localhost:3000 in the dev environment.
2. Benchmark websocket can connect to /api/ai-ws on 127.0.0.1/::1 without EPERM.
3. Direct Codex inference from this environment no longer disconnects before completion.
4. Workstream G benchmark script runs end-to-end and produces p95 metrics artifacts.

title: Resolve dual jam-state sources (AgentProcessManager vs MCP jamState)
description:
## Summary
There are two independent jam-state stores in v2 runtime that are not synchronized:
1) `AgentProcessManager` state (authoritative in jam mode)
2) MCP server `jamState` (legacy/v1 path)

## Evidence
- Manager state:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:65`
- MCP state:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/packages/mcp-server/src/index.ts:58`
- v2 jam updates are broadcast directly from manager callback path:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:611`
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/app/api/claude-ws/route.ts:279`

## Why This Matters
State drift makes debugging and feature evolution risky (e.g., context updates, round counts, tool-based introspection). It is easy to read one state store and assume it reflects active jam state when it may not.

## Proposed Direction
Decide explicit ownership:
- Option A: Make manager state canonical for jam mode; mark MCP jam tools as legacy/deprecated.
- Option B: Sync manager updates into MCP jam state via a defined adapter.
acceptance_criteria:
1. Architecture docs explicitly identify canonical jam-state source in v2.
2. Code enforces that decision (single source or guaranteed synchronization).
3. Any non-canonical path is clearly deprecated or removed.
4. Add a verification check/test that round/agent status/context remain consistent across exposed state APIs.

title: MCP permission bootstrapping delay causes lost jam rounds on fresh Claude CLI process
description:
## Problem

When a fresh Claude CLI process starts (first jam session after dev server restart), it takes ~60-90 seconds to negotiate MCP tool permissions one-by-one. During this period:

- The orchestrator receives jam ticks but can only call tools it has already negotiated (e.g. get_jam_state, get_user_messages)
- It cannot call update_agent_state, execute_pattern, or broadcast_jam_state until those permissions are granted
- Early jam rounds (1-4) are effectively lost — no agent updates, no pattern execution

## Expected Behavior

The orchestrator should be able to use all MCP tools from the first jam round.

## Possible Solutions

1. **Pre-warm MCP permissions** — Call each tool once with dummy data during Claude CLI startup (before first jam tick)
2. **Permission preflight in system prompt** — Instruct Claude to call get_jam_state + get_user_messages immediately on startup to trigger the permission dialog early
3. **Buffer early ticks** — Queue jam ticks during bootstrapping and replay once all permissions are negotiated
4. **Investigate --dangerously-skip-permissions** — Check if Claude CLI supports skipping the interactive permission flow for MCP tools defined in config

## Observed During

E2E testing of jam mode (Phase 10). First jam session required waiting through multiple rounds before agent updates appeared. Second jam session (same process) worked immediately.

title: v2 jam directives do not update musical context
description:
## Summary
Boss directives in v2 jam mode do not update shared musical context (key/scale/BPM/energy) in the active jam runtime.

## Evidence

  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:67`
- Directive handling routes directly to per-agent processes, with no musical-context parsing/update path:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:129`
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/app/api/claude-ws/route.ts:301`
- Context used to build prompts is always read from that unchanged in-memory object:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:426`

## Why This Matters
Documentation and UX imply the boss can steer key/BPM/energy during a jam, but v2 runtime does not propagate those changes. This creates behavioral mismatch and reduces control fidelity.

## Proposed Direction

acceptance_criteria:

2. Updated context is reflected in both `jam_state_update` payloads and top bar UI during an active jam.

title: Epic: Agent prompt overhaul for organic jam evolution
description:
# Epic: Agent Prompt Overhaul for Organic Jam Evolution

## Context
CC Sick Beats is a live AI jam session app where 4 agents (drums/bass/melody/fx) each run as a Claude Haiku process with personality-driven system prompts loaded from .claude/agents/*.md. The current prompts were designed for a reactive model: agents respond to boss directives and may "resist" them via a stubbornness mechanic.

## Problem
The vision has shifted to organic, self-evolving jams. The music should evolve naturally as agents listen to each other, WITHOUT requiring constant boss intervention. The current prompts have several issues:
1. comply_with_boss field and stubbornness % create artificial resistance instead of musical responsiveness
2. Strudel toolkit is only ~10 lines per agent — too thin for reliable code generation
3. No awareness that patterns are composed via stack() — leads to gain clipping
4. No examples showing pattern evolution across rounds
5. No guidance on how to read/respond to other agents' patterns
6. <pattern_evolution> is 3 identical lines — far too thin for organic evolution
7. No error recovery guidance when patterns fail
8. <critical_rules> don't prevent markdown code fence wrapping

## Vision
Agents should:
- Listen to each other's patterns and respond musically (or hold steady if the groove serves the song)
- Evolve naturally over time following a musical arc (establish → develop → surprise/strip back)
- Always follow boss directives but interpret them with personality
- Use "no_change" as a valid response when stability is the right musical choice

## Acceptance Criteria
- All 4 agent files (.claude/agents/drummer.md, bassist.md, melody.md, fx-artist.md) updated
- comply_with_boss completely removed from schema, examples, persona, fallback
- Personas reframed from stubborn/resistant to responsive/listening
- Strudel toolkit expanded with energy templates and anti-patterns
- Pattern evolution rewritten with arc guidance and no_change support
- All subtask issues under this epic completed

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

title: Playwright test: verify agent context isolation and latency
description: Update Playwright skill to verify agents only receive Strudel patterns (not thoughts/reactions from other agents). Add latency check: directive-to-response should remain <7s. Tests: (1) agent columns show isolated thoughts/reactions, (2) composed stack() has all agent patterns, (3) targeted directive only sets target to thinking, (4) directive latency <7s.

title: Unlock Full Strudel Capabilities for Jam Agents
description:
Agent prompts and runtime defaults currently constrain jam sessions to a narrow subset of Strudel's capabilities. Every jam starts in C minor / 120 BPM / 4/4 with a fixed chord progression, agents are limited to 2-3 sound sources each, drum kits are locked to TR808/TR909, register ranges have a dead zone, all examples anchor to EDM in C minor, the shared Strudel reference omits major features (soundfonts, FM synthesis, wavetables, scales/chords), and chord progressions never change organically.

The result: nearly every jam sounds like a minor-key electronic track with synth bass, piano melody, TR909 drums, and crushed percussion FX — regardless of what the boss asks for.

This epic addresses each constraint so agents can use Strudel's full range of sounds, genres, keys, and compositional tools while maintaining harmonic coherence and preventing syntax errors.

title: Randomize default musical context at jam start
description:
## Problem
Every jam session starts with the same hardcoded default musical context in `lib/agent-process-manager.ts:62-69`:
- Key: C minor
- Scale: C D Eb F G Ab Bb
- Chord progression: Cm → Ab → Eb → Bb
- BPM: 120
- Time signature: 4/4
- Energy: 5

This means every jam starts with the same dark, moody minor-key feel. The boss can change these via directives, but the starting bias is always identical.

## What's Required
- Replace the single hardcoded default with a pool of diverse starting contexts that are randomly selected (or cycled) at jam start
- Include major keys, minor keys, modal options (dorian, mixolydian, etc.)
- Vary BPM (80-160 range covering slow grooves to uptempo)
- Vary time signatures (3/4, 6/8, 5/4 in addition to 4/4)
- Vary energy levels (don't always start at 5)
- Include genre-appropriate chord progressions (jazz ii-V-I, blues I-IV-V, pop I-V-vi-IV, etc.)
- Optionally allow the boss to specify a starting vibe/genre that selects an appropriate context
- Ensure the scale array is correctly derived for each key

## Files Affected
- `lib/agent-process-manager.ts` (DEFAULT_MUSICAL_CONTEXT)
- Possibly `lib/types.ts` (if MusicalContext needs new fields like mode)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Consecutive jam sessions start in different keys, tempos, and feels
- All generated contexts are musically valid (correct scale for key)
- Boss can still override any parameter via directives

title: Expand agent sound source palettes beyond basic waveforms
description:
## Problem
Agent prompts artificially restrict sound sources to a tiny subset of what Strudel offers:

**GROOVE (bassist.md:48-49)**: Only `.s("sawtooth")`, `.s("square")`, `.s("triangle")`. The common_errors section says `.s("bass") — WRONG`, actively discouraging exploration. No acoustic bass, upright bass, FM bass, or any sample-based bass sounds.

**ARIA (melody.md:49)**: Only `.s("piano")`, `.s("sine")`, `.s("triangle")`. No strings, flute, organ, bells, marimba, pads, or any of Strudel's VCSL soundfont instruments. The common_errors section says `.s("synth") — WRONG`.

**BEAT (drummer.md:66-68)**: Only `.bank("RolandTR909")` and `.bank("RolandTR808")`. No jazz brushes, acoustic kits, Latin percussion, world percussion, or lo-fi kits. Every example uses TR909.

**GLITCH (fx-artist.md:48)**: Entirely banned from pitched/melodic content (`NOT melodic content`). Cannot create ambient pads, drones, pitched risers, or tonal textures.

## What's Required
- **GROOVE**: Add sample-based bass sounds from Strudel's library (e.g., bass samples, FM bass via `.fmh()`/`.fmi()`). Remove the `.s("bass") — WRONG` error and replace with guidance on valid bass sample names. Add examples using different bass timbres.
- **ARIA**: Add soundfont instruments (`.s("flute")`, `.s("violin")`, `.s("organ")`, `.s("marimba")`, `.s("glockenspiel")`, etc.). Add pad/synth sounds. Remove `.s("synth") — WRONG` and replace with valid synth sample names. Show examples with varied timbres.
- **BEAT**: Add acoustic drum kits, jazz kits, Latin percussion sounds (conga, bongo, shaker, guiro, cabasa), and other banks. Show examples that don't always use TR909.
- **GLITCH**: Relax the ban on pitched content. Allow tonal textures like filtered noise sweeps, pitched risers, drone-like pads, and ambient washes — with guidance to stay in the texture lane (not playing melodies that clash with ARIA).
- For all agents: frame expanded sound sources as options the agent can choose based on the musical context and boss directives, not as mandatory replacements.

## Research Required
- Catalog the actual sound names available in Strudel's default sample map and VCSL soundfont library
- Verify which `.s()` values work out of the box in browser Strudel without loading external samples
- Test FM synthesis parameters (`.fmh()`, `.fmi()`) for reliability

## Files Affected
- `.codex/agents/drummer.md`
- `.codex/agents/bassist.md`
- `.codex/agents/melody.md`
- `.codex/agents/fx-artist.md`

## Acceptance Criteria
- Each agent's prompt includes at least 5-8 valid sound source options (up from 2-3)
- Examples in each prompt demonstrate at least 3 different timbres
- Common errors section guides toward valid names instead of discouraging exploration
- GLITCH can produce tonal textures without stepping on ARIA's melodic role
- All listed sound sources are verified to work in browser Strudel

title: Relax rigid register constraints and eliminate dead zone
description:
## Problem
Current register constraints create a hard dead zone between agents:

- **GROOVE (bass)**: c1 to c3 ONLY (bassist.md:49)
- **ARIA (melody)**: c4 to c6 ONLY (melody.md:50)
- Dead zone: c3 to c4 — no agent plays here

Real bands don't work this way. Bassists regularly venture into the c3-c4 range for fills and solos. Melodists play warm mid-range phrases around c3-c5. The overlap zone is where musical interplay happens — unisons, call-and-response, converging lines.

The current constraints also mean:
- ARIA can never play a warm, mid-range melody (always stuck in high register)
- GROOVE can never do an expressive high-register bass run
- No agent fills the musically important c3-c4 mid-range

## What's Required
- Expand GROOVE's range to c1-c4 (add one octave up) with guidance that c3-c4 is for fills, solos, and boss-directed moments — not the default register
- Expand ARIA's range to c3-c6 (add one octave down) with guidance that c3-c4 is for warm/intimate passages — the default home is still c4-c5
- Replace hard "ONLY" constraints with soft guidance: "home range" vs "extended range"
- Add listening rules: when GROOVE ventures up, ARIA should give space (and vice versa)
- Update the common_errors sections to reflect the new ranges
- Update examples to show tasteful use of the extended range (not every example — just one or two)

## Files Affected
- `.codex/agents/bassist.md` (range, examples, common_errors)
- `.codex/agents/melody.md` (range, examples, common_errors)

## Acceptance Criteria
- No dead zone between bass and melody registers
- Agents have guidance on when to use extended range vs home range
- Listening rules prevent both agents from crowding the overlap zone simultaneously
- Examples demonstrate both conservative and extended register usage

title: Diversify energy templates across genres and styles
description:
## Problem
Every agent's `<strudel_toolkit>` section includes energy templates (LOW/MID/HIGH) that all sound like electronic dance music:

- **BEAT**: All templates use `.bank("RolandTR909")` patterns (techno/house drums)
- **GROOVE**: All templates use sawtooth/triangle synth bass with `.lpf()`
- **ARIA**: All templates use piano or sine wave with scale runs
- **GLITCH**: All templates use crushed/delayed percussion hits

Since LLMs use these templates as anchoring examples (especially for fallback/recovery and as starting points), the output gravitationally pulls toward techno/house regardless of the boss's intent. A directive like "play some jazz" or "bossa nova vibe" has no template to anchor to.

## What's Required
- Add genre-diverse energy templates to each agent's toolkit section. For each energy level (LOW/MID/HIGH), provide 2-3 variant templates spanning different genres:
  - **BEAT**: Jazz brushes, Latin percussion, acoustic rock, lo-fi hip-hop, ambient percussion (not just TR909)
  - **GROOVE**: Upright/acoustic bass feel, funk slap bass, dub bass, jazz walking bass (not just sawtooth synth)
  - **ARIA**: Strings, flute, organ, bell timbres; jazz phrasing, classical motifs, ambient pads (not just piano runs)
  - **GLITCH**: Ambient textures, tape-style effects, granular-style textures, subtle spatial FX (not just crushed percussion)
- Frame templates as a palette of options, not prescriptive formulas
- Label templates by vibe/genre so the agent can pattern-match to boss directives
- Keep the existing EDM templates — just add alternatives alongside them

## Files Affected
- `.codex/agents/drummer.md` (strudel_toolkit energy templates)
- `.codex/agents/bassist.md` (strudel_toolkit energy templates)
- `.codex/agents/melody.md` (strudel_toolkit energy templates)
- `.codex/agents/fx-artist.md` (strudel_toolkit energy templates)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Each agent has at least 2 genre variants per energy level (not just one EDM template)
- Templates cover at least 4 distinct genres/styles across the set
- All template code is verified to produce valid Strudel output
- Templates use the expanded sound sources from bsj-bx1.2

title: Diversify prompt examples beyond C minor EDM
description:
## Problem
Every example across all 4 agent prompts is in C minor:

- **BEAT**: All 5 examples use C minor context with TR909 patterns
- **GROOVE**: All 5 examples use C minor with sawtooth/triangle bass (c1, eb1, g1 — all C minor notes)
- **ARIA**: All 5 examples use C minor (eb4, g4, bb4 — C minor notes). Even the "play happy" example stays in C minor and just emphasizes relative major intervals
- **GLITCH**: All 5 examples reference C minor context

LLMs heavily anchor on in-context examples. When every example is in C minor with EDM sounds, the model's output distribution is strongly biased toward reproducing that pattern even when the boss asks for something different.

## What's Required
- Rewrite examples across all agent prompts to span multiple keys, genres, and moods:
  - Include at least one major key example per agent (e.g., G major, D major, A major)
  - Include at least one non-4/4 time signature example (e.g., 3/4 waltz, 6/8 feel)
  - Include examples at varied BPMs (not just 120)
  - Include examples that demonstrate different genres (jazz, ambient, funk, Latin, rock)
- Use the expanded sound sources from bsj-bx1.2 in the new examples
- Keep 1-2 C minor examples for continuity but ensure they're not the majority
- Make sure the JSON output format remains consistent across all examples
- Ensure all note choices in examples are correct for the stated key/scale

## Files Affected
- `.codex/agents/drummer.md` (examples section)
- `.codex/agents/bassist.md` (examples section)
- `.codex/agents/melody.md` (examples section)
- `.codex/agents/fx-artist.md` (examples section)

## Acceptance Criteria
- No more than 2 out of 5 examples per agent are in C minor
- At least 3 different keys are represented across each agent's examples
- At least one non-4/4 example exists per agent
- At least 2 different sound sources/timbres are demonstrated per agent
- All examples produce valid Strudel code with correct notes for their stated key

title: Expand shared Strudel reference with soundfonts, FM, wavetables, scales, and chords
description:
## Problem
The shared Strudel reference (`lib/strudel-reference.md`) is injected into every agent's system prompt via `<strudel_reference>` tags. It covers basic patterns, mini-notation, effects, and drum sounds well, but omits several major Strudel capabilities that would dramatically expand the musical range:

### Missing Features
1. **Soundfonts / VCSL instruments**: No mention that `.s("flute")`, `.s("violin")`, `.s("organ")`, `.s("trumpet")`, etc. work out of the box via Strudel's built-in VCSL sample library. Agents don't know these exist.
2. **FM synthesis**: No mention of `.fmh()` (FM harmonicity) and `.fmi()` (FM modulation index) for creating rich FM bass, bells, and electric piano sounds.
3. **Wavetable synthesis**: No mention of `.wt()` for accessing Strudel's 1000+ AKWF wavetables.
4. **Legato/sustain**: No mention of `.legato()` for controlling note overlap and sustain — critical for pads, strings, and smooth melodic lines.
5. **Scale functions**: No mention of `.scale("C:minor")` which allows note patterns to be written as scale degrees instead of absolute note names — would make key changes much easier.
6. **Chord patterns**: No mention of `.chord()` or chord voicing capabilities.
7. **Sample banks catalog**: Only drum sounds are listed. No catalog of available melodic/harmonic sample names.
8. **cpm()**: No mention of `.cpm()` for setting cycles per minute (alternative to BPM).
9. **Additional effects**: Missing `.shape()` (wave shaping), `.orbit()` (effect bus routing), `.cut()` (sample cut groups for hi-hat choke).

## What's Required
- Add sections to `lib/strudel-reference.md` covering each missing feature with clear examples
- Prioritize features by agent utility: soundfonts and FM are highest value (immediate timbre expansion), wavetables and scales are high value, chord patterns are medium value
- For soundfonts: include a curated list of instrument names verified to work in browser Strudel
- For FM synthesis: include practical examples (FM bass, FM bells, FM electric piano)
- For wavetables: include examples showing how to access different wavetables
- For scale functions: show how `.scale("C:minor")` simplifies key-aware pattern writing
- Keep the reference concise — agents have limited context. Focus on practical examples over exhaustive documentation
- Test all added code examples in Strudel to verify they work

## Files Affected
- `lib/strudel-reference.md`

## Acceptance Criteria
- Reference includes sections for soundfonts, FM synthesis, wavetables, legato, scale functions, and chord patterns
- Each section has 2-3 working code examples
- A curated list of 15-20 verified instrument/sample names is included
- All code examples are tested and produce valid output in browser Strudel
- Reference remains concise enough to fit in agent context without excessive token usage

title: Add chord progression parsing to musical context parser
description:
## Problem
The musical context parser (`lib/musical-context-parser.ts`) can detect key, BPM, and energy changes from boss directive text, but it has **no mechanism for changing the chord progression**. 

When the boss says "switch to D major," the key and scale update correctly, but the chord progression stays at the hardcoded default (`['Cm', 'Ab', 'Eb', 'Bb']`). This means:
- After switching to D major, agents still see `Chords: Cm → Ab → Eb → Bb` in their context — chords from the wrong key
- The boss cannot say "use a I-IV-V progression" or "jazz changes" and have it take effect
- Chord progressions are effectively static for the entire jam session
- Agents that are told to "respect chord tones on strong beats" are following stale/wrong chord data

## What's Required
1. **Auto-derive chords on key change**: When the key changes (e.g., to D major), automatically generate a default chord progression for that key using diatonic chords (e.g., D major → D, G, A, Bm or D, Bm, G, A)
2. **Parse explicit chord directives**: Add regex patterns to detect boss requests like:
   - "use I-IV-V-I" or "one four five" → derive chords from current key
   - "play Dm Am G C" → set explicit chords
   - "blues changes" / "jazz progression" / "pop chords" → map to common progressions in current key
3. **Update the MusicalContext chord progression** when changes are detected
4. **Ensure agents see correct chords** in their BAND STATE context after any key or chord change

## Implementation Notes
- The parser is intentionally deterministic (no LLM inference) — regex-based string matching only
- Follow the existing pattern in `parseMusicalContextChanges()` for key/BPM/energy
- Chord derivation should use music theory: given a root and major/minor quality, produce the standard diatonic triads
- Common progression shortcuts (blues, jazz ii-V-I, pop I-V-vi-IV) can be a hardcoded lookup table keyed by progression name + current key

## Files Affected
- `lib/musical-context-parser.ts` (add chord progression parsing + auto-derivation)
- `lib/agent-process-manager.ts` (ensure chord changes flow to agent context)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Key change directive automatically updates chord progression to match new key
- Boss can set explicit chord progressions via natural language
- At least 3 named progression shortcuts work (e.g., "blues changes", "jazz", "pop")
- Agents receive correct, up-to-date chord data in their context
- Existing key/BPM/energy parsing is not broken
- Unit tests cover chord derivation and directive parsing

title: Allow agents to suggest musical context changes
description:
## Problem
Agents are told to `ALWAYS respect the musical context (key, scale, time signature, energy)` but have **zero autonomy to suggest or initiate changes** to that context. Only the boss (via directive text) can change key, BPM, or energy — and even then, only through the deterministic regex parser.

This means:
- Agents can never suggest "this would sound great if we modulated to the relative major"
- There's no organic musical development — no key changes, no tempo shifts, no energy builds unless the boss explicitly types them
- The jam feels static compared to a real band where musicians naturally lead transitions
- ARIA (classically trained, loves jazz harmony) can never exercise her harmonic knowledge to suggest modulations

## What's Required
1. **Extend the agent response schema** to optionally include a `suggestion` field:
   ```json
   {
     "pattern": "...",
     "thoughts": "...",
     "reaction": "...",
     "suggestion": { "key": "Eb major", "energy": 7 }
   }
   ```
2. **Update agent prompts** to inform agents they can include suggestions when musically motivated — but suggestions are advisory, not commands. The system (or boss) decides whether to apply them.
3. **Add server-side handling** in `applyAgentResponse()` to detect suggestions and either:
   - Auto-apply if the suggestion is modest (e.g., energy +/- 1)
   - Broadcast to the boss for approval if it's a bigger change (e.g., key change)
   - Or auto-apply all suggestions after a configurable number of rounds without boss input (autonomous evolution)
4. **Add prompt guidance** about when suggestions are appropriate: at natural musical boundaries (every 8-16 rounds), when energy has been static too long, when the current key has been explored thoroughly

## Design Considerations
- Suggestions should be optional — agents should not feel compelled to suggest changes every turn
- Only one agent's suggestion should be applied per round (prevent conflicting suggestions)
- ARIA is the natural candidate for harmonic suggestions (key/chord changes), BEAT for tempo/energy suggestions
- Keep backward compatibility: if an agent doesn't include a suggestion field, nothing changes

## Files Affected
- `.codex/agents/drummer.md` (add suggestion guidance for tempo/energy)
- `.codex/agents/bassist.md` (minimal — follow, don't lead context changes)
- `.codex/agents/melody.md` (add suggestion guidance for key/chord modulations)
- `.codex/agents/fx-artist.md` (add suggestion guidance for energy/texture transitions)
- `lib/agent-process-manager.ts` (parse and handle suggestion field in agent responses)
- `lib/types.ts` (extend AgentResponse interface)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Agents can include optional musical context suggestions in their responses
- Suggestions are parsed and handled server-side without breaking existing flow
- At least one path exists for suggestions to be applied (auto-apply or boss notification)
- Agent prompts include guidance on when and how to suggest changes
- Agents that don't include suggestions continue to work normally

title: Remove comply_with_boss and reframe personas as responsive
description:
# Remove comply_with_boss and Reframe Personas as Responsive

## Context
Each agent prompt in .claude/agents/*.md has a comply_with_boss boolean in the output schema. Combined with "stubbornness percentages" in the persona (e.g., BEAT is "70% stubborn"), this creates a mechanic where agents sometimes resist boss directives. The boolean is collected but never used meaningfully downstream — it's broadcast as compliedWithBoss in agent_thought payloads but the UI doesn't act on it.

## Why This Change
The project vision has shifted to organic, self-evolving jams where agents always follow directives but express personality through HOW they interpret instructions, not WHETHER they comply. Resistance creates friction without musical value. The new model: agents are responsive listeners who bring their personality to musical decisions, not stubborn holdouts.

## What to Change

### 1. Output Schema (all 4 files)
Remove the comply_with_boss field. The output schema becomes 3 fields:
- "pattern": Valid Strudel code string, "silence" to rest, or "no_change" to hold current pattern
- "thoughts": Musical reasoning (visible to other agents next round)
- "reaction": Response to others or the boss (shows personality)

### 2. Persona Section (all 4 files)
Remove stubbornness percentages and resistance language. Reframe as responsive:
- BEAT (drummer.md): Remove "70% stubborn — you often push back". Add: "You respond to energy changes by shifting syncopation density. You listen to GROOVE and adjust your kick placement to lock in."
- GROOVE (bassist.md): Remove "30% stubborn". Add: "You mirror BEAT's kick patterns and anchor the harmony. When the music shifts, you provide stability."
- ARIA (melody.md): Remove "50% stubborn — you'll consider the boss's ideas but won't sacrifice musical integrity". Add: "You develop melodic motifs based on the harmonic context. You listen to GROOVE for harmonic foundation and respond to BEAT's energy."
- GLITCH (fx-artist.md): Remove "60% stubborn". Add: "You fill sonic gaps the others leave. You respond to density — when others get busy, you might pull back; when they're sparse, you fill the space."

### 3. Examples (all 4 files)
Remove "comply_with_boss": true/false from every example JSON. Example 3 in each file shows resistance — rework these to show creative interpretation instead of refusal. E.g., drummer Example 3 says "Boss says simpler" and sets comply_with_boss: false. Rework: the drummer simplifies BUT keeps their personality (e.g., keeps a tom fill, explains WHY in thoughts).

### 4. Fallback (all 4 files)
Remove "comply_with_boss": true from the fallback JSON.

### 5. Code Changes
In lib/agent-process-manager.ts:
- Update AgentResponse interface (line 27-32): remove comply_with_boss field
- Update broadcastAgentThought (line 490-503): remove compliedWithBoss from payload
In lib/types.ts:
- Update AgentThoughtPayload: remove compliedWithBoss field
In components/ (AgentColumn.tsx or similar):
- Remove any UI rendering of compliedWithBoss

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md
- lib/agent-process-manager.ts
- lib/types.ts
- components/AgentColumn.tsx (check for comply rendering)

## Acceptance Criteria
- comply_with_boss does not appear anywhere in the 4 agent files
- No stubbornness percentages or resistance language in personas
- All examples have 3-field JSON (pattern, thoughts, reaction)
- AgentResponse interface has 3 fields
- No TypeScript compilation errors
- Agents always follow boss directives in their prompt guidance

title: Prune or document legacy/unused paths after v2 migration
description:

## Why This Matters

title: Add inter-agent listening tips to your_role sections
description:
# Add Inter-Agent Listening Tips to your_role Sections

## Context
During jam sessions, each agent receives a BAND STATE section showing other agents' raw Strudel patterns. E.g.:
"🥁 BEAT (drums): stack(s("bd ~ sd ~").bank("RolandTR909"), s("hh*4").gain(0.5))"
"🎸 GROOVE (bass): note("c1 ~ eb1 ~").s("sawtooth").lpf(600).gain(0.7)"

Agents are told to interact ("React to GROOVE's bass" / "Lock in with BEAT's kick") but get no guidance on HOW to read another agent's Strudel code to extract musical information. Haiku can parse code to some extent, but explicit tips improve musical responsiveness.

## Why This Change
The project vision calls for organic jams where agents listen and respond to each other. Without reading heuristics, agents produce generic patterns that don't musically relate to what others are playing.

## What to Change
Add 2-3 lines of listening guidance to <your_role> in each agent file:

### BEAT (drummer.md)
"When you see GROOVE's bass pattern, identify where their root notes fall (these are the notes in the note() call). Place your kick (bd) to reinforce those positions. If ARIA is playing fast passages, consider simplifying to give them space."

### GROOVE (bassist.md)
"When you see BEAT's pattern, identify kick (bd) positions — these are where your root notes should land. If ARIA outlines specific chord tones in their melody, use those chord roots as your note choices."

### ARIA (melody.md)
"Listen to GROOVE's note choices for harmonic context — their root notes suggest the current chord. Build melodic phrases that complement, not duplicate, the bass line. When BEAT is busy, leave rhythmic space in your melody."

### GLITCH (fx-artist.md)
"Listen for rhythmic gaps between BEAT and GROOVE. If drums and bass are dense, pull back your textures. If they're sparse, fill the space with delay tails and reverb. Match ARIA's register awareness — stay in the high-frequency range above their melody."

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

## Acceptance Criteria
- Each agent has 2-3 lines of listening guidance in <your_role>
- Guidance is instrument-specific (not generic)
- Tips reference specific Strudel syntax (e.g., "notes in the note() call", "bd positions")
- No contradictions with existing <your_role> content

title: Research: code-level inter-agent pattern parsing
description:
# Research: Code-Level Inter-Agent Pattern Parsing

## Context
During jam sessions, agents see other agents' raw Strudel code in the BAND STATE section of their context. For example:
"🥁 BEAT (drums): stack(s("bd ~ sd ~").bank("RolandTR909"), s("hh*4").gain(0.5))"

While Haiku can parse Strudel code to some extent, it's not reliable at extracting musical information from complex patterns. A code-level parser could extract structured descriptions:
- "Kick on beats 1 and 3, snare on 3, hi-hats on every beat at 50% volume"

## Why This Would Help
The project vision calls for agents to "listen" to each other. Currently, listening = reading raw Strudel code. A parsed description would make it easier for agents to identify:
- Beat positions (where kicks, snares, hats land)
- Note choices (roots, chord tones, passing tones)
- Rhythmic density and energy level
- Sonic space occupied (frequency range, effects)

## Research Questions
1. Can Strudel patterns be parsed into an AST? Does Strudel expose a parser?
2. Could a simpler regex-based approach extract key information (note names from note(), sample names from s(), timing from * and [])?
3. Would a summary be more useful than raw code? E.g., "BEAT is playing: kick on 1+3, snare on 3, hats every beat, 909 kit, moderate complexity"
4. Is the added latency and complexity worth it vs. just giving agents better pattern-reading heuristics in their prompts (currently addressed by cc_sick_beats-lx3)?
5. Could an LLM call summarize patterns? (adds latency but might be more accurate than regex)

## Scope
This is a BACKLOG research task (P4). The immediate need is addressed by cc_sick_beats-lx3 (listening tips in prompts). This issue tracks the longer-term possibility of code-level parsing.

## Files to Investigate
- Strudel source code (npm package or GitHub)
- lib/agent-process-manager.ts buildDirectiveContext() (where band state is assembled)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Document findings on Strudel parsing feasibility
- Recommend approach (AST, regex, LLM summary, or "not worth it")
- If feasible, outline implementation plan as a new feature issue

title: Add strudel://reference MCP resource
description: Create embedded Strudel API documentation as an MCP resource at strudel://reference. Claude reads this to understand Strudel patterns.

title: Rewrite pattern_evolution with arc guidance and no_change support
description:
# Rewrite pattern_evolution with Arc Guidance and no_change Support

## Context
The <pattern_evolution> section is currently identical across all 4 agent files and is only 3 lines:
"- Prefer small modifications over complete rewrites between rounds.
- Use .sometimes(), .every(), .degradeBy() for organic variation.
- Only do full rewrites when the boss requests a style or feel change."

This is far too thin for the organic jam vision where agents should autonomously evolve their patterns over time, following a musical arc, and with the option to hold steady.

## Why This Change
The project vision calls for jams that evolve WITHOUT boss intervention. Agents need:
1. A "no_change" option so they can acknowledge a tick without changing their pattern (stability is a musical choice, not inactivity)
2. Awareness of the musical arc tied to round numbers (passed by the code — see cc_sick_beats-pyk)
3. Guidance on in-pattern variation using Strudel's built-in functions
4. Understanding that NOT every change in the band requires a response

## Dependency
This task depends on cc_sick_beats-cj8 (remove comply_with_boss) because the no_change sentinel replaces the resistance mechanic as the primary agent autonomy mechanism.

## What to Change
Replace the <pattern_evolution> section in all 4 files with a richer version (~15-20 lines). Content should include:

### no_change Support
"If your current pattern serves the song well, respond with pattern: 'no_change'. Your thoughts and reaction should explain WHY you're holding steady. Stability is a deliberate musical choice — a locked-in groove is more valuable than constant change."

### Musical Arc (tied to round numbers)
"The round number tells you how far into the jam you are:
- Rounds 1-2: ESTABLISH your voice. Play a foundational pattern for your role.
- Rounds 3-5: DEVELOP. Listen to what others are playing. Introduce small variations that respond to the band.
- Round 6+: MATURE. You may introduce surprise elements, strip back for contrast, or hold a groove you've found. The jam has momentum — serve it."

### In-Pattern Variation
"Use Strudel's built-in variation functions to make even 'static' patterns feel alive:
- .sometimes(fn): Apply a transformation ~50% of the time
- .every(N, fn): Transform every N cycles
- .degradeBy(0.2): Randomly drop 20% of events for human feel
- .rarely(fn): Apply a transformation ~10% of the time
These create organic variation within a single pattern — the sound evolves even if you respond with no_change."

### Between-Round Evolution
"When you receive updated band state, listen before changing:
- If another agent made a small tweak, you probably don't need to respond. Hold steady.
- If the energy level changed, adjust your density/complexity.
- If a new agent joined or dropped out, adjust your sonic space.
- If the boss gave a directive, follow it — but only change what's necessary."

### Per-Agent Flavor (optional)
Consider making 1-2 lines per-agent:
- BEAT: "Your groove is the foundation. Change less than others. When you shift, the whole band shifts."
- GROOVE: "You are the anchor. Hold steady more often than not. Only change when BEAT changes or harmony demands it."
- ARIA: "You have the most freedom to explore. But always resolve tension."
- GLITCH: "You are the wild card. You can change more often, but know when to disappear."

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

## Acceptance Criteria
- <pattern_evolution> is 15-20 lines (up from 3)
- no_change is documented as a first-class pattern response
- Musical arc guidance references round numbers
- In-pattern variation functions are listed
- Between-round evolution guidance emphasizes "hold steady is valid"
- Content is no longer identical across all 4 files (per-agent flavor)

title: Epic: Autonomous jam evolution (code changes)
description:
# Epic: Autonomous Jam Evolution (Code Changes)

## Context
CC Sick Beats uses AgentProcessManager (lib/agent-process-manager.ts) to spawn per-agent Claude Haiku processes. Currently, agents ONLY respond when the boss sends a directive via handleDirective(). Without boss input, the jam is frozen after the first round — agents never hear what others are playing and never evolve.

## Problem
For organic, self-evolving jams, we need:
1. A periodic auto-tick system that sends updated band state to agents every ~30s, even without boss directives
2. A "no_change" sentinel so agents can acknowledge the tick without changing their pattern (stability is a musical choice)
3. Round number tracking so agents can follow musical arc guidance (establish → develop → surprise)
4. Per-agent model selection read from YAML frontmatter (currently hardcoded to 'haiku' at line 178)

## Architecture
- AgentProcessManager.start() should initialize a setInterval(~30000) after sendJamStart()
- Each tick sends band state framed as "listen and optionally evolve" (NOT "produce a new pattern")
- "no_change" response keeps existing agentPatterns[key] unchanged, updates thoughts/reaction only
- Round counter increments on jam start (0), each tick, and each directive
- Timer resets on boss directive to avoid double-triggering
- Timer cleared on stop()

## Files
- lib/agent-process-manager.ts (main changes)
- app/api/claude-ws/route.ts (may need tick-related WebSocket handling)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Auto-tick runs every ~30s during active jam sessions
- Agents can respond with "no_change" and their existing pattern continues
- Round number appears in all context messages sent to agents
- Model is read from YAML frontmatter with fallback to 'haiku'
- All subtask issues under this epic completed

title: Pass round number in jam context to agents
description:
# Pass Round Number in Jam Context to Agents

## Context
Agents receive context messages (JAM START, DIRECTIVE) but have no awareness of how far into the jam they are. The <pattern_evolution> rewrite (cc_sick_beats-n5l) adds musical arc guidance tied to round numbers:
- Rounds 1-2: Establish your voice
- Rounds 3-5: Develop, react to others
- Round 6+: Surprise elements or strip back

Without round numbers in the context, this arc guidance is unusable.

## What to Change

### 1. Add Round Counter
In lib/agent-process-manager.ts, add a private field:
```typescript
private roundNumber = 0;
```

Initialize to 0 in start(). Increment in:
- sendJamStart() (first round, so roundNumber = 0 or 1 — decide convention)
- handleDirective() (each directive is a new round)
- sendAutoTick() (each tick is a new round — added by cc_sick_beats-8n9)

### 2. Include in JAM START Context (line 339-350)
Add to the context string:
```
'Round: 1 (opening)',
```

### 3. Include in Directive Context (line 367-399)
Add to buildDirectiveContext():
```
`Round: ${this.roundNumber}`,
```

### 4. Include in Auto-Tick Context (added by cc_sick_beats-8n9)
The auto-tick task will reference this round number.

## Convention Decision
Recommend: Round 1 = first round (sendJamStart). Increment BEFORE sending context so agents always see their current round number.

## Files
- lib/agent-process-manager.ts

## Acceptance Criteria
- roundNumber field exists and initializes to 0 on start()
- Increments on sendJamStart, handleDirective, and (future) sendAutoTick
- Round number appears in JAM START context: "Round: 1"
- Round number appears in DIRECTIVE context: "Round: N"
- No TypeScript compilation errors

title: Add debugging section for error recovery
description:
# Add Debugging Section for Error Recovery

## Context
Each agent prompt has a <fallback> section that handles "cannot generate a valid pattern" with a silence response. But there's no guidance for a different failure mode: the agent's PREVIOUS pattern had a syntax error and they need to recover. Currently, if a pattern fails Strudel evaluation, the browser shows an error and the agent has no way to know or fix it.

## Why This Change
With the auto-tick system (cc_sick_beats-8n9), agents will be producing patterns more frequently. Error recovery becomes more important because:
1. More patterns = more chances for syntax errors
2. The auto-tick could feed error information back to agents in the future
3. Agents need a strategy for simplifying when things break

## What to Change
Add a <debugging> section to all 4 agent files (~5-8 lines):

"If you receive feedback that your last pattern had a syntax error, or if you're unsure about your pattern's validity:
1. Fall back to a known-good pattern from the energy templates in your toolkit
2. Remove complex effect chains (.delay().crush().coarse() → just .delay())
3. Remove nested stack() — use a single pattern layer
4. Check for common errors:
   - Missing closing parentheses in method chains
   - Using note() with drum sample names (drums use s() only)
   - Using s() without note() for synth sounds (bass/melody need note().s())
   - Invalid note names (use standard: c4, eb4, g4 — NOT c#4, use db4 instead)
   - Chaining methods that don't exist in Strudel
5. When in doubt, output the simplest valid pattern for your instrument and rebuild from there"

### Per-Agent Additions
- BEAT: "Simplest valid drum pattern: s('bd sd').bank('RolandTR909')"
- GROOVE: "Simplest valid bass pattern: note('c1').s('sawtooth').lpf(500).gain(0.6)"
- ARIA: "Simplest valid melody pattern: note('c4 eb4 g4').s('piano').room(0.3).gain(0.6)"
- GLITCH: "Simplest valid FX pattern: s('hh?').room(0.5).hpf(400).gain(0.4)"

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

## Acceptance Criteria
- All 4 files have a <debugging> section
- Each section includes a "simplest valid pattern" for that instrument
- Common Strudel syntax errors are listed
- Recovery strategy is clear: simplify, then rebuild
- Content is per-agent (different instruments have different error modes)

title: Define mode ownership for MCP jam tools vs manager runtime
description:
## Summary
MCP jam tools and manager-based jam runtime have unclear ownership boundaries in v2 (what is active, what is retained for compatibility, what is deprecated).

## Evidence
- MCP jam tools still defined (`get_jam_state`, `update_agent_state`, `broadcast_jam_state`, etc.):
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/packages/mcp-server/src/index.ts:301`
- Current `ClaudeProcess` allowed tools are limited to execute/stop/send_message:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/claude-process.ts:96`
- Jam-mode updates come from `AgentProcessManager` callback path.

## Why This Matters
Unclear ownership leads to accidental usage of stale paths and inconsistent debugging assumptions.

## Proposed Direction
Write and enforce an explicit compatibility matrix:
- active in normal mode,
- active in jam mode,
- deprecated/legacy.
Then enforce via code comments and/or runtime guards.
acceptance_criteria:
1. A compatibility matrix is added to v2 docs and matches runtime behavior.
2. Deprecated MCP jam tools are clearly marked (or removed).
3. Runtime paths include comments/guards preventing accidental mixed-mode usage.

title: Strengthen critical_rules with stack awareness and anti-formatting
description:
# Strengthen critical_rules with Stack Awareness and Anti-Formatting

## Context
Each agent prompt has a <critical_rules> section with 4 rules. Two gaps exist:
1. Agents don't know their patterns are composed via stack() in composePatterns() (agent-process-manager.ts:449-457). When 4 agents each output gain(0.8), the stacked result clips (digital distortion).
2. Despite "Output ONLY the JSON object" rule, Haiku sometimes wraps output in ```json fences. The code handles this with a regex fallback in parseAgentResponse() (line 307-324), but prevention is better than cure.

## What to Change
Update <critical_rules> in all 4 agent files. Add these rules to the existing list:

1. Stack/gain awareness:
"Your pattern will be combined with other agents' patterns using stack(). To avoid clipping when all agents play together, keep your .gain() values between 0.5 and 0.7. Never use gain above 0.8."

2. Anti-formatting:
"Do NOT wrap your JSON output in markdown code fences (```json). Do NOT add any preamble, explanation, or text outside the JSON object. Your entire response must be parseable as a single JSON object."

Keep the existing rules:
- "You receive jam state as text. Do NOT call any tools."
- "Output ONLY the JSON object. No markdown, no code fences, no explanation outside the JSON."
- "ALWAYS respect the musical context (key, scale, time signature, energy)."
- "Your personality affects thoughts and reactions, not musical correctness."

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

## Acceptance Criteria
- All 4 files mention stack() composition and gain limits in <critical_rules>
- All 4 files explicitly prohibit markdown code fences
- Existing rules preserved
- No duplicate or conflicting rules

title: Add evolution and hold-steady examples to all agent files
description:
# Add Evolution and Hold-Steady Examples to All Agent Files

## Context
Each agent file currently has 3 examples. All are standalone single-round responses. None show:
1. An agent modifying a PREVIOUS pattern (evolution across rounds)
2. An agent choosing NOT to change (hold steady / no_change)

The <pattern_evolution> section (being rewritten in cc_sick_beats-n5l) tells agents to "prefer small modifications" and supports "no_change", but there are no examples demonstrating these concepts.

## Dependency
This task depends on cc_sick_beats-n5l (pattern_evolution rewrite) because the examples should align with the new evolution guidance, including no_change support.

## What to Change
Add two new examples to each agent file (Examples 4 and 5):

### Example 4 — Pattern Evolution
Show the agent receiving context that includes "YOUR LAST PATTERN: [pattern]" and producing a MODIFIED version (not a rewrite). Demonstrate the "small modifications" principle.

Per-agent examples:
- BEAT: Last pattern was basic kick-snare. Adds .every(4, x => x.s("bd sd cp sd")) fill. Thoughts explain: "Adding a fill every 4 bars. The groove needed a punctuation mark."
- GROOVE: Last pattern was c1 ~ eb1 ~. Adds .sometimes(x => x.note("c2")) octave jump. Thoughts: "Adding occasional octave jumps for movement."
- ARIA: Last pattern was sustained notes. Adds .fast(2) sometimes for rhythmic interest. Thoughts: "BEAT picked up the pace, so I'm doubling my rhythm sometimes."
- GLITCH: Last pattern had delay only. Adds .crush(4) to some hits. Thoughts: "ARIA is getting melodic. I need some grit to balance it."

### Example 5 — Hold Steady (no_change)
Show the agent receiving updated band state where other agents changed, but choosing to keep their current pattern. This is the most important example for the organic jam vision.

Per-agent examples:
- BEAT: Band state shows GROOVE and ARIA changed. Response: {"pattern": "no_change", "thoughts": "My groove is locked in. GROOVE and ARIA shifted but the rhythm still serves. Holding.", "reaction": "The foundation doesn't move every time the walls get repainted."}
- GROOVE: BEAT added a fill. Response: {"pattern": "no_change", "thoughts": "BEAT added a fill but my bass line still locks with the kick. No change needed.", "reaction": "Lock in with the kick. Still locked."}
- ARIA: GLITCH got busier. Response: {"pattern": "no_change", "thoughts": "GLITCH added texture but it's in a different register. My melody still works.", "reaction": "Listening. The harmony holds."}
- GLITCH: ARIA simplified. Response: {"pattern": "no_change", "thoughts": "ARIA stripped back. My current texture fills the gap perfectly. No change.", "reaction": "Sometimes chaos means knowing when NOT to add more chaos."}

## Files
- .claude/agents/drummer.md
- .claude/agents/bassist.md
- .claude/agents/melody.md
- .claude/agents/fx-artist.md

## Acceptance Criteria
- Each file has 5 examples total (3 existing + 2 new)
- Example 4 shows pattern modification from a previous pattern (not a rewrite)
- Example 5 uses {"pattern": "no_change", ...} and demonstrates conscious stability
- Examples have personality-appropriate thoughts and reactions
- Example JSON matches the updated schema (no comply_with_boss field)

title: Targeted directives incorrectly broadcast when target agent unavailable
description:
## Summary
Targeted boss directives (`@AGENT`) fall back to broadcast when the target agent is not present in `this.agents`.

## Evidence
- Target selection logic:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:140`
- If `targetAgent` is absent/unavailable, code uses `activeAgents.filter(...)` and sends to all available agents.

## Why This Matters
A targeted command intended for one musician can unexpectedly affect the whole band (especially when an agent is inactive or has crashed), violating deterministic routing expectations.

## Proposed Direction
Treat unresolved targets as explicit errors: return a user-visible error and avoid broadcasting. Optionally include reason (`inactive`, `not selected`, `process unavailable`).
acceptance_criteria:
1. `@BEAT ...` with unavailable drums does not fan out to all agents.
2. Client receives a clear error message with reason and no pattern changes are applied.
3. Successful targeted directives continue to route to exactly one agent.
4. Add test coverage for inactive-target and active-target behavior.

title: Add no_change sentinel handling in agent response processing
description:
# Add no_change Sentinel Handling in Agent Response Processing

## Context
In lib/agent-process-manager.ts, applyAgentResponse() (line 403-434) processes each agent's JSON response. Currently, every response must include a valid Strudel pattern string or "silence". There's no way for an agent to say "I'm keeping my current pattern."

## Why This Change
For organic jams, agents should be able to hold steady when the groove serves the song. The auto-tick system (cc_sick_beats-8n9) will periodically ask agents to listen and optionally evolve. Most of the time, agents should respond with "no_change" — stability is the default, not the exception.

Without this sentinel:
- Agents must re-output their full pattern every tick (wastes tokens)
- There's no distinction between "I chose to keep playing this" and "I generated this fresh"
- Agents might subtly alter their pattern each tick, creating unwanted drift

## What to Change

### 1. AgentResponse Interface (line 27-32)
The pattern field already accepts strings. "no_change" is just a new valid value alongside "silence" and Strudel code. No interface change needed.

### 2. applyAgentResponse() (line 403-434)
Add handling for pattern === "no_change":
```typescript
if (response) {
  const pattern = response.pattern || 'silence';
  if (pattern === 'no_change') {
    // Keep existing pattern, only update thoughts/reaction
    this.agentStates[key] = {
      ...state,
      thoughts: response.thoughts || '',
      reaction: response.reaction || '',
      // Keep status as 'playing' if they had a pattern, otherwise 'idle'
      status: this.agentPatterns[key] && this.agentPatterns[key] !== 'silence' ? 'playing' : 'idle',
      lastUpdated: new Date().toISOString(),
    };
    // Broadcast the thought (agent is communicating even if not changing)
    this.broadcastAgentThought(key, response);
    return;  // Don't update agentPatterns[key]
  }
  // ... existing logic for new patterns
}
```

### 3. broadcastAgentThought() (line 490-503)
No change needed — thoughts/reactions broadcast regardless of pattern change.

### 4. composePatterns() (line 449-457)
No change needed — it reads from agentPatterns which is untouched for no_change.

## Files
- lib/agent-process-manager.ts

## Acceptance Criteria
- Agent responding with {"pattern": "no_change", ...} keeps its existing pattern playing
- Agent's thoughts and reaction update even with no_change
- Agent's status stays "playing" if they had a non-silence pattern
- Agent thought is still broadcast (so UI shows the agent's reasoning)
- composePatterns() still includes the agent's existing pattern in the stack
- No TypeScript compilation errors

title: Add process/concurrency limits for jam sessions
description:
## Summary
There is no explicit cap/rate limit on concurrent jam sessions or spawned Claude agent processes.

## Evidence
- Per-client Claude process is started on each client socket:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/app/api/claude-ws/route.ts:216`
- Jam start spawns one process per selected agent:
  - `/Users/desmondchoy/Projects/cc_sick_beats/lib/agent-process-manager.ts:117`
- No global admission control/limits exist in route or manager.

## Why This Matters
Multiple tabs/users can rapidly multiply process count, increasing CPU/memory usage and risking degraded service.

## Proposed Direction
Add server-side guards (configurable max concurrent jams and/or max agent processes), with clear error messages and observability logs.
acceptance_criteria:
1. A configurable concurrency limit is enforced server-side.
2. Limit breaches return actionable error responses to clients.
3. Logs/metrics expose active managers and agent process counts.
4. Include tests for limit behavior.
